subject: Re: how to use ExceptionTestCase ?
msgSnippet: ... exception.Exception1Test has no ... I have been using ExceptionTestCase successfully for several projects. The advantage of having special TestCase class
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Lucas <lucas.bline@l...> wrote:
> import junit.extensions.ExceptionTestCase;
>
> public class Exception1Test extends ExceptionTestCase {
>
> public Exception1Test(String arg0, Class ex) {
> super(arg0, ex);
> }
>
> public void testThis() throws Exception {
> assertTrue(true);
> // no exception by now, but should work anyway
> }
> }
>
>
> the above code gives the following error:
>
> junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: Class
exception.Exception1Test has no
> public constructor TestCase(String name)
>

I have been using ExceptionTestCase successfully for several
projects. The advantage of having special TestCase class is:
1. Separates Exceptional behaviour test code. Throwing exception can
be slower compared to normal workflow. Failure on exception class can
be classified as exceptable for code shipment, while normal test
failure has to be a showstoper.
2. Fails if wrong exception class thrown or nothing was thrown.
3. Typical exception cause is wrong method parameters or
preconditions. So it takes a lot of tests to be written to create
different exceptional conditions.

Futher extension of ExceptionTestCase I would like to see is
a "TestSuite suite(ExceptionClass class)" method that builds a suite
of tests based on retrospective information, when all test methods
throw the same exception class.
